Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Case law supporting Plaintiff's claim includes:
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The claimed proposition is generic and incomplete (“Case law supporting Plaintiff's claim includes:”), but in context this opinion clearly provides plaintiff‑favorable authority on premises liability in a self‑service grocery store slip‑and‑fall. The court expressly adopts the mode of operation approach, relaxes the traditional notice requirement, and reverses summary judgment for the defendant, all of which are supportive of a plaintiff’s negligence claim arising from a supermarket fall.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt:
Because we conclude that the defendant had notice of the inherent risks associated with the operation of its self-service grocery store, we now adopt the mode of operation approach, and we reverse the judge’s decision and remand the case for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
...
In sum, the adoption of the mode of operation approach will not modify the general rule governing premises liability... [but] if a plaintiff proves that an unsafe condition... was reasonably foreseeable, resulting from an owner’s self-service business or mode of operation... the plaintiff will satisfy the notice requirement.

Doe v. Stop & Shop Companies, Inc., 390.raw_text: Doe v. Stop & Shop Companies, Inc., 390 Mass. 185 (2002)
Doe v. Stop & Shop Companies, Inc., 390.proposition: Case law supporting Plaintiff's claim includes:
Doe v. Stop & Shop Companies, Inc., 390.support_reasoning: The user-provided proposition is incomplete (“Case law supporting Plaintiff's claim includes:”) and does not identify any specific legal rule. The opinion itself is a defamation case holding that the radio host’s statements were nonactionable opinion based on disclosed facts and granting summary judgment for defendants. Without a concrete stated proposition, and given that the case is defense-favorable and narrows defamation liability, it cannot be said to support an unspecified plaintiff-side claim.
Doe v. Stop & Shop Companies, Inc., 390.relevant_excerpt: “In sum, we conclude that the challenged statements could only be reasonably understood as expressions of opinion based on nondefamatory disclosed facts. We further conclude that opinions (as contrasted with false and defamatory statements of fact) based on disclosed but false statements of fact are not actionable because they are mere opinion and not statements of fact. Therefore, we reverse the order of the Superior Court judge denying the defendants’ motions for summary judgment and order that judgments for the defendants be entered.”

Smith v. Grocery Store, Inc., 325 Mass..raw_text: Smith v. Grocery Store, Inc., 325 Mass. 123 (1999)
Smith v. Grocery Store, Inc., 325 Mass..proposition: Case law supporting Plaintiff's claim includes:
Smith v. Grocery Store, Inc., 325 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition is incomplete: it only says, “Case law supporting Plaintiff's claim includes,” without identifying what specific legal principle or claim this citation is supposed to support. The opinion itself concerns whether a resulting trust arose where legal title was placed in the defendant’s name but the beneficial interest was intended for the plaintiff’s decedent. Without knowing the actual proposition (e.g., about resulting trusts, ‘straw’ title holders, statute of frauds, etc.), I cannot reliably say that the case supports it.
Smith v. Grocery Store, Inc., 325 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “It is settled that, when a person pays the purchase price of property and takes title in the name of another, without more, the beneficial interest in the property enures to the person who pays the purchase price, by way of resulting trust. … We understand the term ‘straw’ … to mean a person who holds a naked title for the benefit of another… A trust resulted, first in favor of Collins and, after his death, of the plaintiffs as his heirs.”

Johnson v. Market Chain, LLC, 280 Mass..raw_text: Johnson v. Market Chain, LLC, 280 Mass. 456 (1995)
Johnson v. Market Chain, LLC, 280 Mass..proposition: Case law supporting Plaintiff's claim includes:
Johnson v. Market Chain, LLC, 280 Mass..support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is a libel case about whether certain newspaper statements are defamatory and whether they are protected as fair comment or privileged reports of judicial proceedings. The proposition provided is incomplete and does not specify any legal principle that this case is being cited to support, and nothing in the excerpt indicates it is about general plaintiff-side authority beyond this specific libel context. Without a concrete stated proposition, the case cannot be said to support it as framed (“Case law supporting Plaintiff's claim includes”) in any meaningful, accurate way.
Johnson v. Market Chain, LLC, 280 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Such a statement in regard to the contents of a ‘complaint’ entered in the Superior Court, in its natural sense, is, at least, reasonably capable of a defamatory meaning and cannot be ruled on demurrer to be harmless… It is not material that the charge against the plaintiff was not made directly but rather by way of repeating an allegation purporting to have been made in a ‘complaint’ entered in court… Neither the defence of truth nor that of privilege on the ground of fair comment is available to the defendant on demurrer.”

Brown v. Retail Giant, Inc., 200 Mass. 5.raw_text: Brown v. Retail Giant, Inc., 200 Mass. 555 (1987)
Brown v. Retail Giant, Inc., 200 Mass. 5.proposition: Case law supporting Plaintiff's claim includes:
Brown v. Retail Giant, Inc., 200 Mass. 5.support_reasoning: The opinion text is about construing an employment contract’s term (weekly vs. one-year employment) and the contingent nature of a potential year-end bonus; there is no mention of Brown, Retail Giant, or any proposition relating to a plaintiff’s claim more generally. Because the proposition is incomplete and non-specific (“Case law supporting Plaintiff's claim includes:”) and the case instead limits an employee’s ability to claim a one-year contract, it does not affirmatively support an unspecified plaintiff-friendly proposition. In fact, its holding is more favorable to the employer than to the employee.
Brown v. Retail Giant, Inc., 200 Mass. 5.relevant_excerpt: “The exception must be sustained. Upon its face the contract was a hiring by the week at the most, and not by the year or for a year. The payments were to be made weekly… In the contract before us there is no language expressly naming one year as the term of employment. Nor is the language such as to imply that such is the understanding of the parties.”

Wilson v. Fresh Foods Corporation, 180 M.raw_text: Wilson v. Fresh Foods Corporation, 180 Mass. 420 (1983)
Wilson v. Fresh Foods Corporation, 180 M.proposition: Case law supporting Plaintiff's claim includes:
Wilson v. Fresh Foods Corporation, 180 M.support_reasoning: The claimed proposition is incomplete and does not identify any specific legal principle (it ends with a colon and simply says that case law supporting Plaintiff’s claim includes this case). Without knowing what precise legal proposition it is being cited for, it is impossible to say that this opinion ‘supports’ it. The case deals with internal governance of a religious corporation, expulsion of members, trustee authority, meeting validity, and the right of members to keep a church open; whether that matches Plaintiff’s unspecified claim cannot be determined from the text provided.
Wilson v. Fresh Foods Corporation, 180 M.relevant_excerpt: “The association is entitled to a decree enjoining the defendants from permanently closing the church building of the association against any religious services held for the public advancement of the worship of God, or to insure religious instruction on Sunday, by any members of the association; and such a decree is to be entered in the case in the Superior Court.”

Lee v. Local Market, Ltd., 150 Mass. 320.raw_text: Lee v. Local Market, Ltd., 150 Mass. 320 (1979)
Lee v. Local Market, Ltd., 150 Mass. 320.proposition: Case law supporting Plaintiff's claim includes:
Lee v. Local Market, Ltd., 150 Mass. 320.support_reasoning: The proposition is incomplete and only says, ‘Case law supporting Plaintiff's claim includes:’ without identifying any specific legal principle. The Lee v. Local Market excerpt concerns the effect of an obstruction (painted glass window) on the validity of a license under a specific statute, not any clearly stated plaintiff-oriented claim. Because no definite proposition is articulated, it cannot be said that this case supports it as framed.
Lee v. Local Market, Ltd., 150 Mass. 320.relevant_excerpt: “Under the Pub. Sts. c. 100, § 12, as amended by the St. of 1882, c. 259, the maintaining by the defendant, upon the premises, of a painted glass window, or of any other obstruction, which interfered with a view of the interior of the premises, or of the business conducted upon the premises, made his license void, although the obstruction existed when the license was granted.”
